message.content: This question requires understanding of how light travels and interacts with surfaces. When a person needs to relocate a light to another room without physically leaving that room, they can redirect the light using reflections. By placing a mirror or reflective surface in the original room and angling it in such a way that it reflects the light towards the desired room, the person can effectively "move" the light without physically relocating it. Option (A) is incorrect as turning off all lights does not solve the problem of relocating the light. Option (B) is irrelevant and destructive, as throwing the light in the yard has nothing to do with relocating it. Option (C) is an unnecessary solution as getting a new lamp does not solve the problem of moving the existing light fixture.

This question requires understanding of how light travels and can be redirected using reflections. If a light needs to be relocated to another room without physically moving it, a person can use mirrors or other reflective surfaces to redirect the light into the desired room. This way, the light will reach the new room without the person having to physically move the light source. Option (A) is incorrect because turning off the lights doesn't involve relocating the light source. Option (B) is incorrect because throwing the light in the yard doesn't solve the problem of moving it to another room. Option (C) is incorrect because getting a new lamp also doesn't address the need to relocate the existing light source.
